articles.headline: Made on the Inside, Worn on the Outside
articles.snippet: Brands are using prison labor to provide inmates with jobs and training. But is it possible — and ethical — to build a profitable fashion business behind bars?
articles.abstract: Brands are using prison labor to provide inmates with jobs and training. But is it possible — and ethical — to build a profitable fashion business behind bars?
articles.lead_paragraph: In a lush valley surrounded by the Peruvian Andes — past two sets of security gates, high fences, barbed wire and a rigorous pat-down — 13 women stood hard at work. They were weaving and knitting luxurious alpaca wool sweaters, deep-pile roll-necks and silky-soft track pants, destined to be sold to wealthy shoppers with lives far away, and a far cry, from their own.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Paton and Andrea Zarate

articles.headline: China Uses DNA to Track Its People, With the Help of American Expertise
articles.snippet: The Chinese authorities turned to a Massachusetts company and a prominent Yale researcher as they built an enormous system of surveillance and control.
articles.abstract: The Chinese authorities turned to a Massachusetts company and a prominent Yale researcher as they built an enormous system of surveillance and control.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The authorities called it a free health check. Tahir Imin had his doubts.

articles.headline: New Election Ordered in North Carolina Race at Center of Fraud Inquiry
articles.snippet: The unanimous ruling by the state Board of Elections was a startling turn in a case that underscored the risks of absentee ballot fraud.
articles.abstract: The unanimous ruling by the state Board of Elections was a startling turn in a case that underscored the risks of absentee ballot fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — North Carolina officials on Thursday ordered a new contest in the Ninth Congressional District after the Republican candidate, confronted by evidence that his campaign had financed an illegal voter-turnout effort, called for a new election.

articles.headline: It Started With a Jolt: How New York Became a Tech Town
articles.snippet: Amazon may not call it home. But the city, by design and because of its allure, is increasingly a magnet for coders and companies.
articles.abstract: Amazon may not call it home. But the city, by design and because of its allure, is increasingly a magnet for coders and companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Euan Robertson started his job with New York City’s economic development team at an ominous moment. It was Monday, Sept. 15, 2008, the day Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy and ignited the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Labor’s Hard Choice in Amazon Age: Play Along or Get Tough
articles.snippet: The battle over Amazon’s New York plans resurfaced tensions among unions over how to deal with Uber, Airbnb and other emerging giants.
articles.abstract: The battle over Amazon’s New York plans resurfaced tensions among unions over how to deal with Uber, Airbnb and other emerging giants.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s one of the most vexing challenges facing the labor movement: how to wield influence in an era increasingly dominated by technology giants that are often resistant to unions.

articles.headline: The Dollar Is Still King. How (in the World) Did That Happen?
articles.snippet: Despite talk that the dollar was losing dominance, it has only gained stature, reinforcing President Trump’s power to dictate foreign policy.
articles.abstract: Despite talk that the dollar was losing dominance, it has only gained stature, reinforcing President Trump’s power to dictate foreign policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A cursory assessment might find the United States a less than ideal candidate for the job of managing the planet’s ultimate form of money.

articles.headline: The Shutdown Made Sara Nelson Into America’s Most Powerful Flight Attendant
articles.snippet: A rising star of the labor movement, she’s made a career of getting unruly people to do what she wants.
articles.abstract: A rising star of the labor movement, she’s made a career of getting unruly people to do what she wants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seven hours before the State of the Union address, Sara Nelson went to Capitol Hill to visit Senator Bernie Sanders. She waited in the reception area of his office until the independent from Vermont emerged, cracked a grin and bear-hugged her: the most powerful flight attendant in America.
